p: The electrochemical characteristics of NiCo 2S 4/N-CNT for Li storage were evaluated by CV and charge–discharge cycling, as shown in Fig. 5 at a potential range of 0.01–3.00 V (vs. Li +/Li). The cathodic process consisted of three reduction peaks (Fig. 5a) situated at 1.71 V, 1.33 V, and 0.70 V. The strongest peak is positioned at 1.33 V, and two weaker peaks correspond to the reduction of NiCo 2S 4 to Ni and Co. In comparison, the peaks at 1.71 V and 0.70 V correspond to the formation of Li 2S and the SEI film, respectively. In the anodic process, the oxidation peaks at 1.33 V and 2.05 V can be attributed to the oxidation of metallic Co to CoS x. In addition, there is an intensive peak at 2.32 V resulting from the oxidation reactions of metallic Ni and Co to NiS x and CoS x, respectively. The shape of the curve, peak position, and the intensity of peaks are relatively stable in the following cycles, indicating that NiCo 2S 4/N-CNT has good stability and reversibility.
